habitat_description:
This species is found in southern New Mexico, central Texas, and Zacatecas, Mexico (Bartlett and Bartlett 1999; Degenhardt et al. 1996; Dixon 2000; Stebbins 2003). It occurs at an elevational range of 300 to 2818 meters (Degenhardt et al. 1996; Stebbins 2003).

The crevice spiny lizard burrows in or using soil, decaying logs, and leaf litter. This species has been described to be closely tied to rocks and crevices as cover and shelter (Degenhardt et al. 1996; Stebbins 2003). The region is characterized by riparian zones, bare rock, talus, scree, desert, cliff, and mixed woodlands.  Habitat of preference includes rocky canyons, hillsides, gullies, rocky outcrops in barren areas, mesquite grassland, creosote bush desert, arid woodland, and spruce-fir forest (Degenhardt et al. 1996).

Strongly associated with rocks and crevices as shelter and cover. Also occurs in mesquite grassland, creosote bush desert, and in communities of oak, pinyon pine, juniper, and spruce-fir forest.
